An unusually large number of
candidates was present at the lacrosse organization meeting held
last Tuesday in the Trophy Room.
This meeting marks the beginning
of indoor training for the 1916 lacrosse squad.
It was a source of satisfaction,
particularly to the coaches, to see
such a large number of freshmen
present. About 50 men in all attended the gathering, and over half
of this number were -new men.
The meeting was presided over
by Captain Sutton who, after a
short speech, introduced as speakers Mr. Duncan Clark, Assistant
Coach Tom Troxell, Dr. Sidney M.
Cone, Coach Reaney Wolfe, Manager Hiram Woodward, and the
veteran of many years, "Father
Bill" Schmeisser.
Coach Wolfe, who is at the head
of the coaching department again
this season, centered his talk mainly on the new men, and spoke of
the fact that, although there are a
great number of old men back this
year, the freshmen who come out
and work steadily have an equal
chance to make the team. In a
short address, Assistant Coach
Thomas Troxell, last year's captain,
also urged the freshmen to come
out for the team, emphasizing the
fact that the squad should be large
if Hopkins wants to have another
championship twelve.
John G. Huck and Thomas Troxell, stars of former Black and Blue
teams, were officially announced
as the assistant coaches for 1916.
This combination, Wolfe. Huck and
Troxell, is hard to improve upon,
and, considering the number of both
new and old men out for the team
this year, prospects for 1916 are exceedingly bright.
That Hopkins has a lacrosse
coaching staff that cannot be
equalled in this country, was the
statement made by Wm.C. Schmeisser, advisor to the team, In a short
speech, "Father Bill," who has had
seventeen years' experience in lacrosse and who is regarded as one
of the leading authorities on the
game in America, spoke in the highest terms of.the men who will develop the 1916 team.
Captain Sutton has decided to
continue the excellent plan adopted
last year for the preliminary work
in the cage. It is his intention to
make a division in the squad, one
set practicing on Monday and
Thursday, and the other on Tuesday and Friday. Practice will be-

About forty men responded to
the call for candidates for the track
team last Thursday, when the organization meeting was held in the
Trophy Room. Among them were
many of the old stars, as well as
several new men whose former
achievements at the sport seem to
Point toward the filling of the holes
left by the graduation last spring
of Ben Tappan and other dependable men.
The meeting was opened by a
short speech by Captain Hall, in
Which he made clear that only hard
and consistent work could bring the
team through the season successfully in the face of the problems
that confront it. As is nearly always the case, the team will start
out with only a nucleus of experienced men, around which a wellbalanced team must be built up out
of the green material.
Captain Hall's speech .was followed by several others by ,the
coach, manager and four or five'old
stars among the alumni, among
Whom were Dr. Eleveth Bridgman,
Messrs. Carroll Stollenwerck, Huntley Lloyd, Merrick and Dr. G.
L. Stewart. All of the speakers
tried to impress upon the candidates
that although track is the sport in
Which individual performancecounts
most, a large amount of team-work
is also necessary.
T.he tentative schedule, as announced by Manager Skinner, is as
follows:
February — Georgetown Meet,
Washington; Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Meet, Baltimore ; Meadowbrook A. C. Meet, Philadelphia;
National A. A. U. Baltimore;
George Washington Meet, Washington • Indoor I. C. A. A. A. A.,
New York.
April 15, open; April 22, Navy,
Annapolis; April 29, Pennsylvania
Relay Carnival, Philadelphia.
May 5-6, S. A. I. A. A. Championships, Richmond, Va.; may 13,
Washington and Lee, Lexington,
Va.; May 26-27, National Intercollegiates, Philadelphia.
It will be seen that this is a most
unusual schedule, in that so many
of the contests will be staged away
from Baltimore. In fact, not a
single meet has been arranged to
take place on Homewood track.
There is still one open date, however, and it is hoped to secure a
contest for Homewood on that day.

HOOFER AGAIN BASEBALL COACH
Former Tri-State Manager to Take Up
Fifth Year as Tutor of Black and
Blue Nine—Material
Looks Good.

The 1916 outlook for baseball is
a very promising one. Eddie Hooper, a former Tri-State League manager, will coach the team for the
fifth season and, as far as present
indications show, the squad will include a large number of experienced men.
Much new pitching material will
be available, since there are several
promising moundsmen among the
freshmen, and there are some at
the Medical School who have as yet
not been out for the team. Butler,
last year's first baseman, and Butts
Sutton, the heavy-hitting left fielder,
will be missing, but,excepting these,
all of the first-string men will again
be out for the team.
• The schedule, which was announced by Manager Chalmers last
week, is as follows:
April 1—Gettysburg, at Gettysburg, Pa.
• April 8—Washington College, at
Homewood.
April 15—Georgetown, at Washington.
April 20—Yale, at Homewood.
April 2I —Harvard, at Homewood.
April 26—Holy Cross, at Homewood.
April 29—Maryland Agricultural College, at Homewood.
May 6—Swarthmore, at Homewood.
May 13—Navy, at Annapolis.
May 20—St. John's, at Homewood.

TRACK MEN ORGANIZE FOR YEAR

During the past month the freshmen, under the supervision of Mr.
Kistler, have organized six basketball teams. Practically every freshman taking gymnasium is a member of one of these teams, and all the
players are at present being given a
chance to learn the game. Mr.
Kistler has adopted this plan as the
best one to ascertain the relative
merits of the players. He expects
to form a freshman team soon after
the Christmas holidays.
Those men who have had experience in basket-ball at prep schools
are playing the best game. A few,
however, who have had no previous
experience are also making a good
showing.
Mr. Kistler is hopeful of a prosperous season. He intends to arrange games with the leading prep
schools and a few colleges, and if
the freshmen continue to show the
,same interest and spirit that preNails among them now their basketball team may be expected to produce results.

Question of His Return as Football Coach
Still Open- Prospects More Favorable than at the Close
of Season.

The question as to whether
Brickley will or will not coach Hopkins' football team next year is still
undecided, but the prospects are decidedy brighter than they were
immediately after the Maryland
Agricultural College game.
There was no real doubt that the
Athletic Association would vote for
Brickley's return, and the action of
this body in ratifying the advice of
the committee appointed to look
into the matter of a coach for next
year's team to endeavor to again
secure Brickley's services caused no
surprise. The only question was
whether the Association would meet
Brickley's terms.
At the present time, if it were
only a matter of terms, Brickley's
return would be assured. He asked
for a substantial increase over the
salary which he was given for his
work of the past season, and this,
after the advisers had recommended
that it be given to him, was granted
at the meeting of the Association
held December 6.
Brickley, however, refuses to give
a definite answer until he has returned from his contemplated trip'
to New England. At the present
time, he says, he himself is ignorant
of his future course of action. His
decision witl probably not be received for ten days or two weeks.
Rumors have been afloat recently
that Brickley was to be offered a
position on the coaching staff of
Harvard, which the leaving of
Haughton has somewhat disorganized. It has also been rumored that
Brickley has received advantageous
business offers from Boston business houses, which would give him
time to assist his alma mater during the football season.
. These offers would, of course,
be very attractive to Brickley.
However, Hopkins rooters can find
consolation in that as yet Brickley
has in no way bound himself, and
the fact that he is still considering
the offer of the Athletic Association seems to attest that there are
excellent chances of his being back
in his old position at Homewood
when next fall's football practice
begins.

At a recent meeting the Athletic
Association voted on the members
of the 1915 football squad who are
to receive the "H" and "H. A. A."
Out of the large squad that practiced all year under Coach Brickley,
nineteen were honored with the "H"
and fourteen more with the "H. A.
A."

Leibensperger, Paul J. Wilkinson,

Stanley, Sonneborn and Brumbaugh.
All the students of Swarthmore
now pay their class dues and other
dues for the support of college activities into the college treasury at
the time of paying their tuition.
This insures every college activity
against being only half-heartedly
supported and makes every student
pay his share.—Ex.
Three colleges of the Northwestern section of the United States
—the University of Washington,
the Washington State College and
the University of Montana—will
inaugurate new presidents next
spring. All three of the new officials have in the past been connected
with Columbia University.—Ex.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 13, 1915.
The Passing of 1915.

With this issue TH4 N4WS-144TTER comes to the end of the fiscal
year 1915. It has been a year marked
throughout its comparatively brief
course by happenings of great import to the present University, and
of brilliant promise for the University that is to be. A new era for
the entire University was heralded
at the dedication of the new buildings at Homewood, and the inauguration of Dr. Prank Johnson Goodnow as the third executive; matters
attendant upon the removal of the
University have brought forth many
innovations in the handling of the
several departments of reference;
general preparations for taking up
the new quarters have been cause
for much interest and comment.
The year 1915 marks the resignation of former Dean Edward H.
Griffin and the selection of Dean
Murray P. Brush to take his place;
it marks the institution of a new
system of undergraduate studies,
and it may be said to mark the last
of the days of the old Johns Hopkins, as 1916 is expected to mark
the beginning of the new.
Undergraduate activities have
been seen to take -6n a new life

within the confines of the passing
year; with the phenomenal success
of the football team under Coach
Brickley at the head of the list, the
accomplishments of the 'several
branches of student interest line up
in most pleasing array. Spirit in
the undertaking of matters purely
under student control has probably
never been more healthy.
Looking back over the successes,
trials and triumphs of the past year
we can find much to encourage us
to make the next year even more
significant in the history of the
University. There is much yet to
be accomplished along all lines, and
the year 1916 offers a splendid time
in which to do the work. The spirit
of the new era is upon us; now is
the time to look forward at what
the coming year has in store for us,
and to prepare to profit by its advantages, share its pleasures, meet
its misfortunes, and, in general, do
everything we possibly can toward
the maintenance of the fair name of
Johns Hopkins.

DR. FINNEY GIVES SECOND TALK

NEW THEORY OF EVOLUTION

Celebrated Hopkins' Surgeon Concludes
Series at Y.M.C. A.on Hygiene -Aler
to Succeed Branham as Asst.Sec.

Dr. H. S. Jennings Announces Result of
_ Experiments Which Show Evolution in
Lower Organisms to Be Gradual.

The chapel services of the University Young Men's Christian Association were led last week by Dr.
John C. French, of the collegiate
faculty. The subject under consideration was that of "Workmanship."
The first service of the week was
devoted to a discussion of workmanship in general, and in the subsequent meetings examples of great
workers were given. The meetings
were all well attended.
On Wednesday, December 8, Dr.
J. M. T. Finney delivered the latter
of his two lectures on the "Fundamentals of Life." These talks have
appeared annually for several years
past in the schedule of lectures of
the Association, and the students
have always displayed a keen interest in them. The lectures this
year were well attended. As has
been customary, the freshmen were
excused from gymnasium work on
the two afternoons, and, although
the lectures are intended primarily
for members of the Freshman
Class, many sophomores and upperclassmen were present.
Dr. Finney spoke in the same
concise and frank manner which has
played an important part in determining the popularity of his past
lectures.
Mr. Robert E. F. Aler, of the
Class of 1916, has been appointed
to fill the vacancy caused by the
resignation of Mr. John C. Branham as assistant general secretary
of the Association. Mr. Aler is particularly well qualified for the position, having had much experience
in handling the work of the Young
Men's Christian Association from
the standpoint of an officer.
There will be no chapel services
this week on account of the proximity of the Christmas examinations, which begin on Friday. The
officers of the Association are well
satisfied to close the year with the
splendid attendance record that has
been established at these services,
and look forward optimistically to
the possibilities of the coming year.

Dr. H. S. Jennings has recently
sent a paper to the National Scientific Society in New York entitled
"Can We Observe Evolution in
Progress of Lower Organisms?'
This paper embodies descriptions of
experiment and of research work
that has been carried on in the
Johns Hopkins University during
the past year, and contains the results of the work and the conclusions drawn therefrom.
The prevalent theory among scientists has been that evolution in
lower organisms took place by leaps
and bounds, and that biological
changes were rapid. However, the
experiments carried on . here in
the University have clearly indicated that evolution is extremely
gradual.
Dr. Jennings' investigations, as
revealed in his article to the National Scientific Society, are farreaching in their effect, for with the
establishment of the fact that evolution in lower organisms is gradual
many of the theories held up to
the present time will be entirel
changed.

HARVARD STARTS COURSE
IN MILITARY TRAINING

On last Thursday Harvard took
a definite stand in the national defense movement. President Lowell
made the announcement that beginning with the next semester a course
in military science would be given
at the university. Major-General
Leonard Wood, assisted by other
army officers, will have charge of
the work of instruction.
All those who take the course in
military science will also learn military tactics from the government
correspondence course, and, in addition, drill instruction will be given.
A committee of undergraduates,
headed by Archie Roosevelt, son of
ex-President Roosevelt, has issued
a call for drill instruction. About
twelve hundred students have signified their intention of taking advantage of this training.

"Senior" Criticizes 1919.

To.the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Whether the action of the
Freshman Class in failing to provide a banner to be torn and defended in the interval between the
halves of the inter-class game this
year was due to a false sense of
economy or a wholly discreditable
desire for "peace at any price,"
their course was certainly one that
should be condemned by the entire
undergraduate body. We have so
few—so very few—traditions at
Hopkins, such a pitiably small
number of things that go to make
an under-classman realize that he
is a freshman or sophomore, not
merely an amiable young man of
praiseworthy aims and moral integrity, that any attempt to decrease
the number should be greeted with
a speedy and official frown. No
mere sheep-skin diploma can suffice
to put the university stamp on graduates who have thought of their
class as only an accidental grouping
of young men united in the pursuit
of Chaucer or the elusive molecule.
There is such a thing as class spirit
and class unity that are as important
as any lecture or any quizz in any
course in the curriculum. This fact
the freshmen seem to have overlooked.
The introduction of the burlap
makeshift with the painted numerals was a praiseworthy attempt to
atone for the earlier error of omission. But it is hardly fair to ask
a large and healthy crowd of sophomores to confine their destructive
tendencies to the rending limb from
limb of a potato sack. Think it
over, 1919. Don't be the class to
take the "hop" out of Hopkins.
Very sincerely,
SENIOR.

December II, 1915.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Anyone who attended the
freshman-sophomore football game
at Homewood on December 4 must
have been struck by both- the remarkably small number of freshmen present and the conspicuous
absence of any fitting or in any
way premeditated class banner.
This is not a criticism of the
Freshman Class—both its football
team and the small number who
were present to participate in the
class rush made extremely good
showings—but a plea that the freshman classes of the future be informed of the customs of the interclass contests, and that these contests themselves receive a larger
degree of University support.
The inter-class rush, held on the
day of the freshman - sophomore
game, is the only form of rivalry
in which all the members of both
classes have a chance to participate.
At the recent rush, however, the
freshmen seemed to be in total ignorance of the time-honored custom of producing a banner for the
sophomores to demolish, and it was
only after the taunts of the latter
and the solicitous advice of the
upper-classmen that a somewhat
scurvy makeshift was produced.
The benefit to the freshmen of.
the rush with the sophomores does
not consist in having a piece of
painted silk—or canvas—torn into
minute shreds; it consists in giving them a feeling of class unity.
It is a wellknown fact that the universities which have keen interclass rivalry generally have welldeveloped college spirit, but even
without this direct corollary any
activity which draws together the
new members of the University
should be heartily encouraged.
The rather shameful exhibition
of two weeks ago was certainly not
the fault of the sophomores—they
were probably as disappointed at
the lack of freshmen as were the
freshmen themselves; nbr can it
be said to have been the fault of
the freshmen. It was the fault of
the want of interest in the event
manifested throughout the University, and of the failure of the upperclassmen to inform the ireshinen Of
what was expected of them. What
seems to have been needed in the
whole affair is what is commonly
designated by the expression "a
HORATIUS.
little more pep."
December 8, 1915.

A most interesting recent gift to
Harvard University is a letter written by Thomas Jefferson from Monticello in 1819 with .advice on the
diet of undergraduates. Jefferson's
suggestions were the following: For
breakfast—Wheat or corn bread, at
choice of each particular, with butter and milk or coffee au lait, at
the choice of each; no meat. For
dinner—A soup, a dish of salt meat,
a dish of fresh meat, and as great a
variety of vegetables, well cooked,
as you please. For supper—Corn
or wheat bread, at their choice, milk
.or coffee au lait, also at their choice,
but no meat: Their drink at all
times water, a young stomach needing no stimulating drinks and the
habit of using them being dangerous. . And 'I should recommend as
late a dinner as the rules of their
school will permit. No game of
chance to be permitted in the house.

Harold Hilton, the well-known
golfer, tells a story of a Scotch
caddie who always wore a "deerstalker" cap with the flap tied tightly down over his ears. One day
somebody noticed that the flaps
were up, and he naturally asked
the reason for the change.
"I hinna had them doon since ma
accident," replied the caddie.
"Accident!" exclaimed the golfer,
"what accident? I haven't heard
about it."
"Ah, well," the caddie explained,
"ye see, a gentlemen offered me a
drink oot o' his whusky flask, an'
I didna hear him."—Ex.

An unusually large number of
candidates was present at the lacrosse organization meeting held
last Tuesday in the Trophy Room.
This meeting marks the beginning
of indoor training for the 1916 lacrosse squad.
It was a source of satisfaction,
particularly to the coaches, to see
such a large number of freshmen
present. About 50 men in all attended the gathering, and over half
of this number were -new men.
The meeting was presided over
by Captain Sutton who, after a
short speech, introduced as speakers Mr. Duncan Clark, Assistant
Coach Tom Troxell, Dr. Sidney M.
Cone, Coach Reaney Wolfe, Manager Hiram Woodward, and the
veteran of many years, "Father
Bill" Schmeisser.
Coach Wolfe, who is at the head
of the coaching department again
this season, centered his talk mainly on the new men, and spoke of
the fact that, although there are a
great number of old men back this
year, the freshmen who come out
and work steadily have an equal
chance to make the team. In a
short address, Assistant Coach
Thomas Troxell, last year's captain,
also urged the freshmen to come
out for the team, emphasizing the
fact that the squad should be large
if Hopkins wants to have another
championship twelve.
John G. Huck and Thomas Troxell, stars of former Black and Blue
teams, were officially announced
as the assistant coaches for 1916.
This combination, Wolfe. Huck and
Troxell, is hard to improve upon,
and, considering the number of both
new and old men out for the team
this year, prospects for 1916 are exceedingly bright.
That Hopkins has a lacrosse
coaching staff that cannot be
equalled in this country, was the
statement made by Wm.C. Schmeisser, advisor to the team, In a short
speech, "Father Bill," who has had
seventeen years' experience in lacrosse and who is regarded as one
of the leading authorities on the
game in America, spoke in the highest terms of.the men who will develop the 1916 team.
Captain Sutton has decided to
continue the excellent plan adopted
last year for the preliminary work
in the cage. It is his intention to
make a division in the squad, one
set practicing on Monday and
Thursday, and the other on Tuesday and Friday. Practice will be-

About forty men responded to
the call for candidates for the track
team last Thursday, when the organization meeting was held in the
Trophy Room. Among them were
many of the old stars, as well as
several new men whose former
achievements at the sport seem to
Point toward the filling of the holes
left by the graduation last spring
of Ben Tappan and other dependable men.
The meeting was opened by a
short speech by Captain Hall, in
Which he made clear that only hard
and consistent work could bring the
team through the season successfully in the face of the problems
that confront it. As is nearly always the case, the team will start
out with only a nucleus of experienced men, around which a wellbalanced team must be built up out
of the green material.
Captain Hall's speech .was followed by several others by ,the
coach, manager and four or five'old
stars among the alumni, among
Whom were Dr. Eleveth Bridgman,
Messrs. Carroll Stollenwerck, Huntley Lloyd, Merrick and Dr. G.
L. Stewart. All of the speakers
tried to impress upon the candidates
that although track is the sport in
Which individual performancecounts
most, a large amount of team-work
is also necessary.
T.he tentative schedule, as announced by Manager Skinner, is as
follows:
February — Georgetown Meet,
Washington; Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Meet, Baltimore ; Meadowbrook A. C. Meet, Philadelphia;
National A. A. U. Baltimore;
George Washington Meet, Washington • Indoor I. C. A. A. A. A.,
New York.
April 15, open; April 22, Navy,
Annapolis; April 29, Pennsylvania
Relay Carnival, Philadelphia.
May 5-6, S. A. I. A. A. Championships, Richmond, Va.; may 13,
Washington and Lee, Lexington,
Va.; May 26-27, National Intercollegiates, Philadelphia.
It will be seen that this is a most
unusual schedule, in that so many
of the contests will be staged away
from Baltimore. In fact, not a
single meet has been arranged to
take place on Homewood track.
There is still one open date, however, and it is hoped to secure a
contest for Homewood on that day.

HOOFER AGAIN BASEBALL COACH
Former Tri-State Manager to Take Up
Fifth Year as Tutor of Black and
Blue Nine—Material
Looks Good.

The 1916 outlook for baseball is
a very promising one. Eddie Hooper, a former Tri-State League manager, will coach the team for the
fifth season and, as far as present
indications show, the squad will include a large number of experienced men.
Much new pitching material will
be available, since there are several
promising moundsmen among the
freshmen, and there are some at
the Medical School who have as yet
not been out for the team. Butler,
last year's first baseman, and Butts
Sutton, the heavy-hitting left fielder,
will be missing, but,excepting these,
all of the first-string men will again
be out for the team.
• The schedule, which was announced by Manager Chalmers last
week, is as follows:
April 1—Gettysburg, at Gettysburg, Pa.
• April 8—Washington College, at
Homewood.
April 15—Georgetown, at Washington.
April 20—Yale, at Homewood.
April 2I —Harvard, at Homewood.
April 26—Holy Cross, at Homewood.
April 29—Maryland Agricultural College, at Homewood.
May 6—Swarthmore, at Homewood.
May 13—Navy, at Annapolis.
May 20—St. John's, at Homewood.

TRACK MEN ORGANIZE FOR YEAR

During the past month the freshmen, under the supervision of Mr.
Kistler, have organized six basketball teams. Practically every freshman taking gymnasium is a member of one of these teams, and all the
players are at present being given a
chance to learn the game. Mr.
Kistler has adopted this plan as the
best one to ascertain the relative
merits of the players. He expects
to form a freshman team soon after
the Christmas holidays.
Those men who have had experience in basket-ball at prep schools
are playing the best game. A few,
however, who have had no previous
experience are also making a good
showing.
Mr. Kistler is hopeful of a prosperous season. He intends to arrange games with the leading prep
schools and a few colleges, and if
the freshmen continue to show the
,same interest and spirit that preNails among them now their basketball team may be expected to produce results.

Question of His Return as Football Coach
Still Open- Prospects More Favorable than at the Close
of Season.

The question as to whether
Brickley will or will not coach Hopkins' football team next year is still
undecided, but the prospects are decidedy brighter than they were
immediately after the Maryland
Agricultural College game.
There was no real doubt that the
Athletic Association would vote for
Brickley's return, and the action of
this body in ratifying the advice of
the committee appointed to look
into the matter of a coach for next
year's team to endeavor to again
secure Brickley's services caused no
surprise. The only question was
whether the Association would meet
Brickley's terms.
At the present time, if it were
only a matter of terms, Brickley's
return would be assured. He asked
for a substantial increase over the
salary which he was given for his
work of the past season, and this,
after the advisers had recommended
that it be given to him, was granted
at the meeting of the Association
held December 6.
Brickley, however, refuses to give
a definite answer until he has returned from his contemplated trip'
to New England. At the present
time, he says, he himself is ignorant
of his future course of action. His
decision witl probably not be received for ten days or two weeks.
Rumors have been afloat recently
that Brickley was to be offered a
position on the coaching staff of
Harvard, which the leaving of
Haughton has somewhat disorganized. It has also been rumored that
Brickley has received advantageous
business offers from Boston business houses, which would give him
time to assist his alma mater during the football season.
. These offers would, of course,
be very attractive to Brickley.
However, Hopkins rooters can find
consolation in that as yet Brickley
has in no way bound himself, and
the fact that he is still considering
the offer of the Athletic Association seems to attest that there are
excellent chances of his being back
in his old position at Homewood
when next fall's football practice
begins.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 13, 1915.
The Passing of 1915.

With this issue TH4 N4WS-144TTER comes to the end of the fiscal
year 1915. It has been a year marked
throughout its comparatively brief
course by happenings of great import to the present University, and
of brilliant promise for the University that is to be. A new era for
the entire University was heralded
at the dedication of the new buildings at Homewood, and the inauguration of Dr. Prank Johnson Goodnow as the third executive; matters
attendant upon the removal of the
University have brought forth many
innovations in the handling of the
several departments of reference;
general preparations for taking up
the new quarters have been cause
for much interest and comment.
The year 1915 marks the resignation of former Dean Edward H.
Griffin and the selection of Dean
Murray P. Brush to take his place;
it marks the institution of a new
system of undergraduate studies,
and it may be said to mark the last
of the days of the old Johns Hopkins, as 1916 is expected to mark
the beginning of the new.
Undergraduate activities have
been seen to take -6n a new life

within the confines of the passing
year; with the phenomenal success
of the football team under Coach
Brickley at the head of the list, the
accomplishments of the 'several
branches of student interest line up
in most pleasing array. Spirit in
the undertaking of matters purely
under student control has probably
never been more healthy.
Looking back over the successes,
trials and triumphs of the past year
we can find much to encourage us
to make the next year even more
significant in the history of the
University. There is much yet to
be accomplished along all lines, and
the year 1916 offers a splendid time
in which to do the work. The spirit
of the new era is upon us; now is
the time to look forward at what
the coming year has in store for us,
and to prepare to profit by its advantages, share its pleasures, meet
its misfortunes, and, in general, do
everything we possibly can toward
the maintenance of the fair name of
Johns Hopkins.

The students of six of the "Big
Nine Universities" have voted to

plan were successful, it might be

DR. FINNEY GIVES SECOND TALK

NEW THEORY OF EVOLUTION

Celebrated Hopkins' Surgeon Concludes
Series at Y.M.C. A.on Hygiene -Aler
to Succeed Branham as Asst.Sec.

Dr. H. S. Jennings Announces Result of
_ Experiments Which Show Evolution in
Lower Organisms to Be Gradual.

The chapel services of the University Young Men's Christian Association were led last week by Dr.
John C. French, of the collegiate
faculty. The subject under consideration was that of "Workmanship."
The first service of the week was
devoted to a discussion of workmanship in general, and in the subsequent meetings examples of great
workers were given. The meetings
were all well attended.
On Wednesday, December 8, Dr.
J. M. T. Finney delivered the latter
of his two lectures on the "Fundamentals of Life." These talks have
appeared annually for several years
past in the schedule of lectures of
the Association, and the students
have always displayed a keen interest in them. The lectures this
year were well attended. As has
been customary, the freshmen were
excused from gymnasium work on
the two afternoons, and, although
the lectures are intended primarily
for members of the Freshman
Class, many sophomores and upperclassmen were present.
Dr. Finney spoke in the same
concise and frank manner which has
played an important part in determining the popularity of his past
lectures.
Mr. Robert E. F. Aler, of the
Class of 1916, has been appointed
to fill the vacancy caused by the
resignation of Mr. John C. Branham as assistant general secretary
of the Association. Mr. Aler is particularly well qualified for the position, having had much experience
in handling the work of the Young
Men's Christian Association from
the standpoint of an officer.
There will be no chapel services
this week on account of the proximity of the Christmas examinations, which begin on Friday. The
officers of the Association are well
satisfied to close the year with the
splendid attendance record that has
been established at these services,
and look forward optimistically to
the possibilities of the coming year.

Dr. H. S. Jennings has recently
sent a paper to the National Scientific Society in New York entitled
"Can We Observe Evolution in
Progress of Lower Organisms?'
This paper embodies descriptions of
experiment and of research work
that has been carried on in the
Johns Hopkins University during
the past year, and contains the results of the work and the conclusions drawn therefrom.
The prevalent theory among scientists has been that evolution in
lower organisms took place by leaps
and bounds, and that biological
changes were rapid. However, the
experiments carried on . here in
the University have clearly indicated that evolution is extremely
gradual.
Dr. Jennings' investigations, as
revealed in his article to the National Scientific Society, are farreaching in their effect, for with the
establishment of the fact that evolution in lower organisms is gradual
many of the theories held up to
the present time will be entirel
changed.

HARVARD STARTS COURSE
IN MILITARY TRAINING

On last Thursday Harvard took
a definite stand in the national defense movement. President Lowell
made the announcement that beginning with the next semester a course
in military science would be given
at the university. Major-General
Leonard Wood, assisted by other
army officers, will have charge of
the work of instruction.
All those who take the course in
military science will also learn military tactics from the government
correspondence course, and, in addition, drill instruction will be given.
A committee of undergraduates,
headed by Archie Roosevelt, son of
ex-President Roosevelt, has issued
a call for drill instruction. About
twelve hundred students have signified their intention of taking advantage of this training.

"Senior" Criticizes 1919.

To.the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Whether the action of the
Freshman Class in failing to provide a banner to be torn and defended in the interval between the
halves of the inter-class game this
year was due to a false sense of
economy or a wholly discreditable
desire for "peace at any price,"
their course was certainly one that
should be condemned by the entire
undergraduate body. We have so
few—so very few—traditions at
Hopkins, such a pitiably small
number of things that go to make
an under-classman realize that he
is a freshman or sophomore, not
merely an amiable young man of
praiseworthy aims and moral integrity, that any attempt to decrease
the number should be greeted with
a speedy and official frown. No
mere sheep-skin diploma can suffice
to put the university stamp on graduates who have thought of their
class as only an accidental grouping
of young men united in the pursuit
of Chaucer or the elusive molecule.
There is such a thing as class spirit
and class unity that are as important
as any lecture or any quizz in any
course in the curriculum. This fact
the freshmen seem to have overlooked.
The introduction of the burlap
makeshift with the painted numerals was a praiseworthy attempt to
atone for the earlier error of omission. But it is hardly fair to ask
a large and healthy crowd of sophomores to confine their destructive
tendencies to the rending limb from
limb of a potato sack. Think it
over, 1919. Don't be the class to
take the "hop" out of Hopkins.
Very sincerely,
SENIOR.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Anyone who attended the
freshman-sophomore football game
at Homewood on December 4 must
have been struck by both- the remarkably small number of freshmen present and the conspicuous
absence of any fitting or in any
way premeditated class banner.
This is not a criticism of the
Freshman Class—both its football
team and the small number who
were present to participate in the
class rush made extremely good
showings—but a plea that the freshman classes of the future be informed of the customs of the interclass contests, and that these contests themselves receive a larger
degree of University support.
The inter-class rush, held on the
day of the freshman - sophomore
game, is the only form of rivalry
in which all the members of both
classes have a chance to participate.
At the recent rush, however, the
freshmen seemed to be in total ignorance of the time-honored custom of producing a banner for the
sophomores to demolish, and it was
only after the taunts of the latter
and the solicitous advice of the
upper-classmen that a somewhat
scurvy makeshift was produced.
The benefit to the freshmen of.
the rush with the sophomores does
not consist in having a piece of
painted silk—or canvas—torn into
minute shreds; it consists in giving them a feeling of class unity.
It is a wellknown fact that the universities which have keen interclass rivalry generally have welldeveloped college spirit, but even
without this direct corollary any
activity which draws together the
new members of the University
should be heartily encouraged.
The rather shameful exhibition
of two weeks ago was certainly not
the fault of the sophomores—they
were probably as disappointed at
the lack of freshmen as were the
freshmen themselves; nbr can it
be said to have been the fault of
the freshmen. It was the fault of
the want of interest in the event
manifested throughout the University, and of the failure of the upperclassmen to inform the ireshinen Of
what was expected of them. What
seems to have been needed in the
whole affair is what is commonly
designated by the expression "a
HORATIUS.
little more pep."
December 8, 1915.

A most interesting recent gift to
Harvard University is a letter written by Thomas Jefferson from Monticello in 1819 with .advice on the
diet of undergraduates. Jefferson's
suggestions were the following: For
breakfast—Wheat or corn bread, at
choice of each particular, with butter and milk or coffee au lait, at
the choice of each; no meat. For
dinner—A soup, a dish of salt meat,
a dish of fresh meat, and as great a
variety of vegetables, well cooked,
as you please. For supper—Corn
or wheat bread, at their choice, milk
.or coffee au lait, also at their choice,
but no meat: Their drink at all
times water, a young stomach needing no stimulating drinks and the
habit of using them being dangerous. . And 'I should recommend as
late a dinner as the rules of their
school will permit. No game of
chance to be permitted in the house.

Harold Hilton, the well-known
golfer, tells a story of a Scotch
caddie who always wore a "deerstalker" cap with the flap tied tightly down over his ears. One day
somebody noticed that the flaps
were up, and he naturally asked
the reason for the change.
"I hinna had them doon since ma
accident," replied the caddie.
"Accident!" exclaimed the golfer,
"what accident? I haven't heard
about it."
"Ah, well," the caddie explained,
"ye see, a gentlemen offered me a
drink oot o' his whusky flask, an'
I didna hear him."—Ex.
